text:

title: Backwards Compatibility Should be a Given For All Apps
text:
I love that Remote (and other Apple apps) are backwards compatible. I own both an iPhone and iPod Touch. The phone runs the latest 3.X firmware, while the Touch runs 2.0. No offense Apple, but I don't feel like paying ten dollars for a firmware update on a device that is currently a dedicated AppleTV remote with other functions that I'll replace with an iPad in a few weeks. 

I recently had to reset my iPod Touch, and forgot that my iPhone had graciously updated all of my apps with 3.0 versions over the past few months. I thought I had lost my 2.0 apps forever. Sure enough, I had lost most of them, as each app I tried to redownload informed me of my incompatible firmware version. I crossed my fingers and found the Remote app. I was afraid that I would have to use my phone as the dedicated AppleTV controller until the iPad was available to purchase, or pay a few bucks for a firmware update on a device that will some be relegated to a single use (phone for on the go, Classic for long plane/train rides, shuffle for working out, Touch for being a couch potato). Lo and behold, the app downloaded, the list and scroll version, not the finger point version of Remote. I was so happy. I can continue to use my touch as a dedicated remote. Thank you for thinking of this, Apple.

text: Wow.  I would've paid more than $9.99 for this app alone, it definitely made the upgrade worth it.  I can go outside, cross the street and still control my music (mind you, i live in NYC). title: This app is great if............
text: Hello everyone. I noticed that a lot of people on here was having a problem with this app and having it communicate with their computer. I have a PowerMac G4 and was suffering from the same problems that everyone here appears to be describing. I found that it all generally boiled down to having the bonjour services working properly. I personally found that the mDNSResponder system service was not active. Now what I ended up doing was turning off my G4. Once it was completely off, I turned it back on while holding down the shift key on my keyboard. What that did was force a "refresh" on the running services that goes on on your Mac. Once it starts up it will say safe mode under the Mac OSX words. Just log in and you should be prompted to allow a system service called mDNSResponder to run. Click allow and now you should restart your computer to get out of safe mode and all should be well with this app and many others. This takes a little while to perform but if you do this correctly you will save yourself hours of headaches. Thats why I rated this app 5 stars and not the customer service or the problems that were experienced when trying to start it less. When the app is functioning it is GREAT!!!! Good luck to all.

title: Wired vs. Wireless - software problem...
text: I was confused by the vast number of bad reviews on the Remote iPhone app.  I'm taking the time to type this because it may help some users.  I have been using the remote app for many years without an issue via with the AppleTV and the iTunes PC on ethernet to my router.  Foo all these years I give it 5 stars.   BUT:  I recently replaced my router and decided to just use the Wireless-N since it is wicked fast.  Thats when the trouble began:  I had hideous problems with configuration and reconnection.  The Apple Remote app could only respond with "Home Sharing Must Be Enabled".  After numerous reboots and reloads on my appleTV, router and iPhone, I reverted to the ethernet connection and THE PROBLEM VANISHED.  The problem is probably within the wireless network config side of the AppleTV.  And the Apple Remote programmers are probably scratching their heads.  With the Apple TV on wireless, the wireless remote app has significant problems connecting.  With the Apple TV on Ethernet all is well and the remote app works like a charm.  If your router is a jumper cable away from the AppleTV, try connecting the AppleTV to the router directly and see if your remote app problems go away.   All of this transpired at the end of FEB2015, and as of this writing it is still working perfectly.

text: Several reviewers have noted their difficulties in making this app connect to their iTunes library. Let me first say, this worked immediately without me having to configure anything! I do networking for a living, so here is what you need to know about this app... It will work if your itunes library is connected via hard-wire to the wireless network as another reviewer said didn't work. You just have to make sure that you don't have seperate networks. The app connects using Bonjour. If you are on Windows, this should have been downloaded with iTunes. If you are on a Mac, well of course, this is already installed! I have a mixed OS environment at home, it works with all 4 of my iTunes libraries, both mac and windows, and all of them can see and connect to the airport express I use for my remote speakers. My central router and gateway is a linksys router (The same kind I am betting more than 80% of you have). Just make sure bonjour is installed and is running as a service in windows if you have problems.

title: A logical progression of the iTunes experience.
text: Remote makes it possible turn on my music just as I walk through the front door or bring up a playlist as guests arrive. Raise or lower volume, skip songs, all without going to a computer. I use three AirPort Express units to dispatch music to different zones in the house creating an immersive experience. Each AirPort Express is connected to a signal sensing amp (it wakes up when audio is sent to it) which in turn is connected to speakers. Using wi-fi and the iPhone I now control iTunes from anywhere in the house. The experience for my guests is magical. Well done Apple, thank you.A note for future improvement: I firmly believe that when using Remote, double clicking the Home button should bring up Remote controls not iPod controls. To arrive at my musical collection the double click of the Home button is the quickest path to take. Few people will want to listen to their iPod when they are listening to home audio.Thank you for reading

title: Nearly perfect, just missing something very essential for a larger iTunes library.
text: This is easily one of the best apps in the store, and the fact that it's free is literally amazing. It has changed the way I listen to my music, as I'm sure it has done for others. However, I don't want to call this a flaw, because that is not what it is, but there is something key that is missing here. With the release of the iPhone 3GS, you now have the ability to activate what you want to hear with "The Voice Activation" feature. This technology is phenomenal. However, and I know I'm not the only person who has over 1000 artists, 10,000 albums, and well over 100,000 songs in my iTunes library. If you are one of these people with a very large library, you know it can take some time to find what you want. Yes, the search feature works pretty well, but it's not as fast as some of us would like. If able, the addition of Voice Activation to this app would make Remote completely perfect. I can't be the only one thinking about this. Apple, what do you say!?

title: Outstanding application, one minor improvement suggestion
text: This application is outstanding and performs as advertised.  It's a simple way to access your audio and video content remotely.I have one minor improvement suggestion which would further allow for true remote functionality.  When accessing video in the iTunes library using this application, I do not believe you have the ability to switch to full screen mode.  If you want to remove the iTunes 'gray frame' (for lack of a better term), you must physically do this at the computer itself.  I have my Mac wired to my TV and stereo from another room.  When choosing a video, it would be nice to be able to play it in full screen mode using simply using this remote application as opposed to making the necessary keystroke on the computer.  I hope such an enhancement could be offered in a future software update.If "Remote" already has this functionality, please let me know.  Many thanks to Apple for offering a powerful tool for the iPhone and iPod Touch at no additional cost.

title: Works flawlessly for me
text:
I'm not sure what everybody else seems to be talking about, but this app has been much better since the update. Sometimes there will be a slight connection issue but It is fixed by going to the list of things to control and reselecting what it was trying to connect to. 

The reason I gave it four stars instead of five is because it doesn't act like a music app.  What I mean is, I can't control the volume with the device's volume buttons and I can't pause or skip to the next song from the lock screen with a double tap of the home button. I realize that permanently being able to access from the lock screen would require an active connection which will greatly drain the battery but since it's already maintaining an active connection for a certain amount of time, I think it's completely reasonable to enable control from the lock screen during that time. 

Overall, excellent app. I recommend those people experiencing connectivity issues make sure they have iOS 6.0.2 and make sure it's not a Wi-Fi connectivity issue.

title: Awesome!
text: This is a very slick and useful app!  I love being able to control iTunes running on my mac when I'm in the next room.  Perfect for stopping the music when I want to watch a movie or go out; and for adjusting the volume.My only complaints are:* Have to be on the same subnet as the iTunes library you want to control.  Not a problem at home, but it means I can't use it at work since our wireless network is on a different subnet than the wired network my PC is on.  Not really a big deal in this case, since I'm never listening to music at work from anywhere other than my office anyway, but it's still an unfortunate limitation, in my opinion.* I frequently turn off WiFi on my iPhone to save on battery life.  The app is much less useful then because it takes longer to join my WiFi network, open up the Remote app, and have it find and connect to iTunes than it would take to walk into the next room...* Cover flow would have been a nice "bells-and-whistle" feature!Still, I'm getting a lot of use out of this app.

title: A Relic
text: This app was novel when it came out in 2008 as a way to play your iTunes library over what is now known as AirPlay to comparable audio devices, but aside from making the app actually work (and that took a while, and some would argue with even that) Apple has put zero effort in expanding the feature set to include the new features of iTunes. The most notable absence is the support of AppleMusic. It would be nice to be able to use Remote to browse the Apple Music library like you can with iTunes and not just your see your own library. And then you can't subscribe to podcasts, buy music, etc... Oh, then of course there are the new bugs with the "Now Playing" queue and how some music you can add and some you can't. (That's always been a mystery, and that's aside from the interface being rather cryptic in the first place.) Clearly Apple wants you to buy an AppleTV to use that for playing music because of course you need a TV device to play music. Those of you with AirPlay-enabled audio devices are stuck with this 9 year old antique. The best you can hope for is that Apple doesn't decide to just yank it from the App Store, so count your blessings, I suppose.
